Hi Kishore,

There are several levels of automation that JTest provides.  Let me 
go into a little bit more detail on each and let me know if there are 
further questions.

1. Automatic White-Box Testing:  Jtest analyzes the structure of the 
class under test then automatically generates test cases in order to 
exercise each method as fully as possible.  Out of the box, there is 
no way for the tool to know exactly what the intended logic of the 
method is, but, we determine all the paths of execution that can be 
taken by a method and automatically generate test cases to force that 
execution.  By doing so, we are generating a large suite of test 
cases that are ensuring the code is robust and not throwing any 
uncaught runtime exceptions, as well as building a suite of tests 
which can be used for regression testing.  As a side note, these 
tests JTest generates can be exported into JUnit test classes.

2: Black Box Testing:  Jtest provides several ways to help speed up 
black box testing as much as possible.  One way to define your own 
tests is by specifying simple values directly in the JTest UI.  The 
second is through JTest's generation of JUnit test classes.  You can 
take the test classes Jtest automatically generates and extend upon 
them to define the logic of the code.  Lastly, Jtest can 
automatically generate a test case template including a corresponding 
testXXX () method, as well as a setUp () and tearDown () method for 
every method in your class.  These testXXX () methods will contain an 
empty test with a "fail" statement that can be replaced with your 
actual test code.

3. Design By Contract:  Design by ContractTM (DbC) is a formal way of 
using comments to incorporate specification information into the code 
itself. Jtest uses the DbC specification information to automatically 
create and execute test cases that verify whether a class or 
component functions as its DbC specification says it should function. 
When you test a class or component with Jtest, Jtest automatically 
creates and executes black-box test cases as part of its normal 
battery of tests. Jtest designs its black-box test cases as follows: 

*If the code has postconditions, Jtest creates test cases that verify 
whether the code satisfies those conditions. 

*If the code has assert conditions, Jtest creates test cases that try 
to make the assertions fail. 

*If the code has invariant conditions, Jtest creates test cases that 
try to make the invariant conditions fail. 

*If the code has preconditions, Jtest tries to find inputs that force 
all of the paths in the preconditions. 

*If the method under test calls other methods that have specified 
preconditions, Jtest determines if the method under test can pass non-
permissible values to the other methods. 

4. Coding Standards:  Since this was brought up in the post, I 
thought I'd clarify what Jtest adds here.  Jtest does not generate 
test cases to check Coding Standards, but it actually parses the 
source code of the .java file and compares it to a list of industry 
guidelines built-in to the tool or any custom rules your group 
defines.  There are currently 326 built in standards and this feature 
is highly customizable.


I hope the above information was enough to help you understand what 
Jtest is actually doing and where it adds value.  If you need 
additional information, please feel free to contact me or visit our 
website, http://www.parasoft.com .

Regards,
David McCaw
ParaSoft Corporation
dmccaw@...
888-305-0041 x1209


--- In junit@y..., "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@s...> wrote:
> Unless I'm wrong, JTest doesn't automatically generate anything 
that will
> test the logic of the classes under test. It automatically tests 
for coding
> standard violations and potentially unhandled exceptions. So to 
test if your
> classes actually work properly (provide services correctly) you'll 
have to
> write tests.
> 
> ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

> SilverMark, Inc.

> > Hi,
> > I want to test a library containing more than 1000 classes and
> > lots of methods. so, it is extreemely difficult for me to write
> > a Testcase(just like having VectorTest class for java.util.Vector 
in
> > the examples given in JUint)for each and every class of my library
> > and a correspoding test method(just like having testCapacity() 
method
> > corresponding to Capacity() method in Java.util.Vector )with 
assert
> > methods.
> > Is there a way to automate this process, i mean given a class can 
a
> > tool generate a corresponding Testclass having all testXXX(),setUp
()
> > and tearDown() methods.
> > please let me know if this kind of feature is available with 
Junit or
